li.p: Can we use global information about a function (average rate of change) to say anything about the local behavior of the function (instantaneous rate of change)?

introduction.p: If you know how a function behaves at every point then you know quite a lot about a function. In fact, this is the whole idea behind plotting points on a coordinate plane in order to determine what the graph of a function looks like. Indeed, given enough local information about a function we can describe it very well globally. However, the opposite is not obviously true. If you know how a function behaves overall, can you say anything about how the function behaves at a specific point? For example, if you knew that f(x) was a parabola, can you determine the value of f(3)? No! In order to determine the value of f(3) you need more information. In general, global information is not enough to determine local information. However, there are some special cases and one such special case is the mean value theorem.

subsection.title: The Mean Value Theorem

example.p: Imagine you have driven a car between Lincoln and Omaha Nebraska, a distance of 59 miles. Suppose that it took you exactly three quarters of an hour to drive this distance. Is it possible that you drove less than 75 miles per hour the entire trip? The average rate of change was 78.67 miles per hour our intuition tells us that at some point on the trip you must have driven at least 78.67 miles per hour. In fact, this is exactly the mean value theorem.

assemblage.title: The Mean Value Theorem
assemblage.p: Let f be a continuous function on the interval [a,b] and differentiable on the interval (a,b), then there exists a number c, with a\lt c \lt b, such that f'(c)=\dfrac{f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}. In other words, f(b)-f(a)=f'(c)(b-a).

subsection.p: A proof of the mean value theorem is outside the scope of the text book. However, it is worth noting that the mean value theorem essentially states that given any secant line between two points on a continuous curve, there is a line tangent to the curve at a point in-between those two points with the property that the slope of the tangent line and slope of the secant line are identical. A geometric representation of the theorem is located in Figure.

figure.caption: To understand this theorem geometrically, look at the figure. Join the points on the curve where x = a and x = b with a secant line and observe that the slope of secant line is given by (f(b) - f(a))/(b - a). Notice that there appears to be at least one point between a and b where the slope of the tangent line to the curve is precisely the same as the slope of the secant line.

statement.p: Consider the function f(x)=2x^3-x on the interval [1,3]. Find the value of c in the interval (1,3) such that f'(c)=\frac{f(3)-f(1)}{3-1}.

hint.p: Use differentiation rules to find the derivative, then evaluate at x=c and solve for c.

solution.p:
We evalute the function at the endpoints of the interval f(3)=16-3=13
f(1)=2-1=1. So, we are trying to find c in the interval (1,3) such that f'(c)=\frac{13-1}{3-1}=6.
Using differentiation rules, we have that f'(x)=6x^2-1, so f'(c)=6c^2-1.

We want to find c such that 6c^2-1=6. Thus, c=\pm\sqrt{\frac{7}{6}}. Since we are looking on the interval (1,3), we find that the value of c on the interval (1,3) such that f'(c)=\frac{f(3)-f(1)}{3-1} is c=+\sqrt{\frac{7}{6}}.

subsection.title: Consequences of the Mean Value Theorem
subsection.p: The Mean Value Theorem has several important consequences that confirm some intuitive ideas that you probably already hold. First, the Increasing Function Theorem establishes that continuous functions with a positive derivative on an interval are increasing on that interval. More specifically,

assemblage.title: The Increasing Function Theorem
assemblage.p:
Suppose that f is continuous on a \leq x \leq b and differentiable on a \lt x \lt b.
If f'(x)>0 on a \lt x \lt b, then f is increasing on a \leq x \leq b.
If f'(x) \geq 0 on a \lt x \lt b, then f is non-decreasing on a \leq x \leq b.

subsection.p: We can also state that a function with a derivative equal to zero on an interval is constant on that interval.

assemblage.title: Constant Function Theorem
assemblage.p: Suppose that f is continuous on a \leq x \leq b and differentiable on a \lt x \lt b. If f '(x) = 0 on a \lt x \lt b, then f is constant on a \leq x \leq b.

subsection.p: We have one final result that can be used to state something you are probably already familier with. The Racetrack Principle argues that if two objects begin at the same place and the same time and one is traveling faster than the other, then the faster object will be ahead of the slower object. Formally, we write the principle in terms of functions.

assemblage.title: The Racetrack Principle
assemblage.p:
Suppose that g and h are continuous on a \leq x \leq b and differentiable on a\lt x\lt b, and that g'(x) \leq h'(x) for a\lt x \lt b.
If g(a)=h(a), then g(x) \leq h(x) for a \leq x \leq b.
If g(b)=h(b), then g(x) \geq h(x) for a \leq x \leq b.

statement.p: Use the Racetrack Principle to show that \ln(x)\leq x-1 for all x\geq 1. Is the statement also true for all 0\lt x \leq 1?

solution.p: Set g(x)=\ln(x) and h(x)=x-1. Both functions are continuous on [1,\infty) and differentiable on (1,\infty).
We take the derivative of each function: g'(x)=\frac{1}{x}, h'(x)=1.
Thus, g'(x)\leq h'(x) for all x\geq 1.
Looking at our functions when x=1, we have that g(1)=\ln(1)=0 and h(1)=1-1=0.
Therefore, by the Racetrack Principle, g(x)\leq h(x) or \ln(x)\leq x-1 for all x\geq 1.
Similarly, if we consider values 0\lt x \leq 1, we have that g'(x)\geq h'(x). Since g(1)=h(1), we have that h(x)\geq g(x) or x-1\geq \ln(x) for all 0\lt x\leq 1.
